heading: us web site outs british spies
subheading: british intelligence struggles for damage control after discovering the names of its secret agents exposed on a us-based web site.
author: reuters
text: senior british intelligence officials are frantically trying to close down a web site that published the names of dozens of alleged intelligence agents, according to reports published thursday calling it the worst breach of national security in years. to avert any risk to the lives of the intelligence agents, the government appealed to british media outlets on wednesday to not divulge the address of the us-based web site or reveal its contents."the published contents could be gravely damaging. officials here [in london] hope they will have this web site removed as speedily as possible," said rear admiral david pulvertaft, who advises the media on matters of national security. "this has underlined the problem with the internet -- that it is unpredictable and uncontrollable."asked how many agents were identified, pulvertaft said: "i would rather not say, but it is a large number."the agents were all reported to have worked for the secret intelligence service (sis), britain's overseas intelligence gathering arm, formerly known as mi6. a report in the financial times said that the web site listed 116 alleged agents of mi6, which was said to employ a full-time staff of about 2,000."we're aware of a recent site claiming to identify officers of the sis," a british foreign office spokesman told reuters. "we do not comment on operational intelligence matters, but publishing any such list is a damaging and irresponsible act."the london evening standard said that the british government obtained a court injunction last week to shut down a web site set up by a mi6 renegade "in which he threatened to out british agents and reveal the location of mi6 offices around the world."some british newspapers said on thursday that it was the worst breach of security in years, but others quoted unidentified officials as insisting that it was not as damaging as cold war incidents. the guardian reported that some of the names were said to be false."to call this the government's ultimate nightmare is an exaggeration," one official was quoted as saying by the financial times."however, within whitehall [where many government offices are located] it was recognised that some british agents had been dangerously exposed to enemy governments or terrorist organisations," the times reported.the times also reported that urgent meetings were under way involving senior civil servants, government lawyers, and intelligence officials.britain operates what is known as a d-notice system, whereby editors agree not to publish information about the intelligence service that might put agents' lives or operations at risk."the us site appears to maintain its own server, rather than being hosted by an internet service provider that could be put under pressure to remove it," the newspaper said.copyright
